description.text: This is a 3-digit, base-10 register for an electromechanical computer I'm working on. It is stepper-driven, and works like a 3-digit counter, counting from 000-999 before rolling over. When all three digit wheels read '0-0-0', 3 reed switches will close and a circuit will be completed to detect the condition.

• Print out 3 copies of the digit wheels, 2 of the 8-tooth gears, and 1 copy of the drive gear.

  • Print out the gear leveler and reed switch holder.

  • Procure two 5/32 brass rods to mount the gear columns on, as well as three 1/8" cube rare-earth magnets, and three reed switches (I got mine from sparkfun.com).

  • Embed the magnets in the digit wheels, and mount the reed switches on the holder. Wire the reed switches in series.

  • Mount everything together, and glue the drive gear to the stepper motor shaft so that it can drive everything.
    • Update: Boom! Added STL versions of the files. Download, print and enjoy. I'd love to hear feedback/improvement/suggestions!

description.text:
(Now available on my Etsy! http://www.etsy.com/shop/3DJoe3D )

UPDATE: Added sliced versions for easier two-color printing, see details below.

Addictive and easy to print, it's everyone's favorite math toy!

It's by far the most fun printed-in-place-hinges toy I've encountered.

I made my own Trihexaflexagon after all my attempts to print whpthomas' model were unsatisfactory, in terms of opening without breaking and flexing without effort. I use an Ultimaker2 and I tried customizing the tolerance up to 0.55 but in vain...

  • Now indented links are looser and print better for me
  • Indented clasp works better for me now with no heating
  • Added chamfers for squished first layers
  • Kept it thin (H=3.5mm)
  • L=190mm (35mm per triangle side)
  • Added a version with 1, 2 and 3 dots
  • Now also a version with patterns!!
  • Now also a blank version, as per request.

I hope this helps. If you make one, please share the pics!!! :)

The original, of course, remains GREAT WORK.

Also I've put this up on Shapeways, in case you want one printed for you!!

The slices for two-color prints were made because I don't like to risk changing colors mid-print. This way it's 3 prints one on top of the other, color 1, color 2, color 1. They each have a 0.3mm frame around them to center them exactly in the same spot on the plate, and to keep slabs b and c floating at the right height. My slicer ignores the frame because the nozzle is 0.4mm, but if your slicer includes the frame for the b and c slabs, the head will probably crash into the already printed layers, so check the print path carefully. (and maybe work around this somehow if that's the case)

Vid: https://youtu.be/jaIunj31xCE
Original: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:141124
About hexaflexagons: https://youtu.be/VIVIegSt81k

If you print it and love it, please do upload a Make and consider tipping! :)
Also please check my profile for my Etsy, Pinshape etc...

comments.text: Hey. Don't know N-Gen, I just order my PLA from China usually... Never had a sticking problem that was due to the materials... Maybe try doing it in one long print instead of changing prints. Measure the lengths of filament to put in the tube accurately enough to change layer color more or less where you want it. Luckily you have some wiggle room, ie at 0.1mm you'll need ~5-10 layers of color A, then ~20 of color B, then the rest in color A... (you'll have to play around with slicers etc to translate that into centimeters of filament.... but it's approx 2cm for each layer of a single hexaflex....) Good luck. Let me know if you try! :)

description.text: In this build i am using a WTF2040-2 Ball Bearing Nut with associated linear screws and FF15, FK15. I got them cheap on ebay, that's the only reason i'm using them here. Its probably a good idea to modify the design for acme screws, that way you can replace the 80 tooth pulley with something smaller. I needed a 4:1 ratio to slow things down, the screws are just too fast. You wont have this problem with acme screws. For the rest of the build, its gonna require drilling about 4 holes on the openrail gantry plates. i still have to figure out how to attach the timing belt to the print head and i'm probably going to have to modify the jhead mount. The rest of the mount can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:108273 The rest of the parts are from OpenBuilds: http://openbuilds.com/ You can see the H-bot, movement here: http://youtu.be/ei4lPk_aM9Y

comments.text: i originally saw this on the Buccaneer from Pirate3d and they where refering to it as a CoreXY movement. Thank You for correcting me.

It uses the same kinematics, but the CoreXY belt design eliminates the "racking" that is typically seen in H-bot designs.  It's likely you'll experience this at some point and may end up redesigning the gantry to be horizontal instead of vertical to accommodate for it.
comments.author: swe3tdave

comments.text:
This is very similar to a design I've had in my head for quite a long time now... I've been thinking about it for over a year but still haven't committed to paper, let alone started building anything.
Anthony, can you tell me what you man by "racking"? I really like the H-Bot gantry design and it's basically the same as CoreXY, but so much cleaner without the crossed belts... I don't like the idea of the belts crossing eachother in CoreXY.

From what i can tell, that "H" is gonna have a mind of its own, the 90 degree angle of the Y axis is gonna move a few degree up and down as the Axis move. With that said, i tried both design, with a piece of cord, a ruler and a few improvised pulleys... i did see the problem with both setup. It was less of a problem with coreXY, but it was still there. I think both design require good pulleys, as smooth as possible, and the belt must be as tight as it can be without obstructing movement. i wonder if it would be better with 4 motors...

title: Bukobot filament spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a spool holder designed to sit on top of your bukobot frame. The spool bracket was designed with a 6mm hole for a steel rod or such rod.   
Anything larger and you might be able to scale up about 10% . otherwise the hole has to be widen by hand. I will upload an STL file without the hole, you might be able use scad or such program to put a hole in.  
The spool it was designed for is a 50mm hole and a depth of about 14mm. I made it specifically for prototypesupply.com 2kg spools. The retaining bracket for the spool will not fit tightly so you are able to remove it if nessesarry. It should require a little force to insert it but once its in it won't fall out easily.  
Any comments or suggestions are welcome

I printed these with PLA but i would imagine they will print fine with ABS. Print out 2 of each: bracket and bracket holder.
  • Put the brackets in slightly at an angle and press firmly to insert them.
  • slide a rod thru the 6mm hole in the bracket holder and thru the bracket.
    • Should spin with no issues.

I have a nice Ozito reciprocating saw that has a LiOn battery pack standard, but I also want to reuse the collection of good quality LiPo (Lithium Polymer) battery packs I have for model planes and helicopters. I've created an adapter to breakout the tools DC contacts neatly to a 3D printed plate that can mount a regular LiPo pack with velcro.
I use 4S packs which are about 16V and the tool runs hard and strong on them, probably because they have less volt drop than the stock LiOn packs.
I've also used LiPo packs to resurrect obsolete NiCd type cordless drills from Bosch and Metabo and they can give good quality tools a new lease of life.
For 12V tools I use 3S Lipo packs, and for 14.4V - 18V I use 4S packs.
(Do it at your own risk of course, as there will be no fault protection from a LiPo pack like the OEM pack may have)
LiPo packs can deliver a lot of current and need to be used correctly when charging and discharging, and I remove the battery from the tool when in storage.

title: Mood Lighting For ToM
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pimp your bot ! These instructions detail how to build software controllable RGB Mood Lighting for your ToM. The mood light is controllable via a new menu on the Gen 4 LCD Interface or via GCodes in ReplicatorG. Your bot can now show it's build status via the color of the mood light. Video (showing functionality):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g3D0ScY6-dg
Video (mood light to music):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FQDFPfnHu9o Additionally, you can set your own RGB color, pick from a predefined list. Also you can pick animated color scenes, for example a Thunderstorm complete with Lightning flashes or signal S.O.S. This is a beginners level project, with a tiny bit of soldering, and is designed for ToM Motherboard V2.4 (the version currently shipping). Required parts are a BlinkM MaxM, RGB Led Strip, a couple of resistors and some bits and pieces you likely have lying around. (full parts list in the pdf). You'll also need:
  • The new Gen 4 Firmware: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15380
  • BlinkM MaxM Holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15374
Download the attached pdf for full instructions

tags: mood light rgb led blinkm maxm blink lighting i2c
Mood Light ToM Firmware BlinkM LED RGB

comments.text: Nice idea.  But would be no support in firmware unless you write it, and also you would need to dedicate CPU cycles away from printing and to driving the color which will likely effect your print quality.  Whereas with a BlinkM it contains a dedicated CPU that takes that task away from your bot.  You could add a ATtiny or Arduino to do this instead, but by that time you have a BlinkM anyway, and you still need to code the CPU and create all the scripts you want.
comments.author: misan

comments.text: He uses the PWM pins of the Arduino, which take fewer CPU cycles to set up than it takes to communicate with a BlinkM.
comments.author: jetty

comments.text: All the PWM pins on Motherboard V2.4 are in use, so no hardware PWM if  you obey the schematic.  Software PWM will take more CPU cycles that Software I2C and would be tough to make work well because of stepper interrupts happening all the time, so you'd get "light" fluctuations or print issues.  Plus you still have to write all the RGB lighting scripts (hardware or software).

title: Cord Clip for Festool D36mm hose

description.text:
Clip this to a 36 mm vacuum hose and then clip on a tool's electrical cord.

I extracted the clip for the source .thing file and ran it through https://modelrepair.azurewebsites.net/ which improved the strength of the center hose retention tabs.

This can also fit 27 mm hoses if you remove the clip from a heated bed while still soft and form it to the 27 mm hose diameter. I used PET-G filament and a bed temp of 80 C.

print_settings.Notes:: Since screws are tapped into the brackets to hold pieces in the dovetail slot and the screws press against the bottom of the slot, use at least 3 perimeters and 3 top layers.  On the last print I used 20% Hexagonal infill on the thicker mounting plate and stiffness was much improved.

title: Layer Cooling Fan Bracket for Geeetech Prusa I3

description.text:
This is a set of items to add a Layer Cooling Fan to a Geeetech Prusa I3 printer or others with similar extruder brackets. The fan duct is not included in these parts. Thanks to AndrewBCN for the inspiration and providing 3 very nice fan ducts. Actually there are 4, but it doesn't look to me like the wrap-around nozzle would work on a dual extruder setup.

Select from the 4 duct styles available at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:540716 , Configurable 40mm fan duct / mount for Wade's extruder.

The parts here include:
A bracket that attaches to the mounting holes on the printer extruder mounting bracket that were intended for a stepper motor cooling fan. The bracket contains two tracks that allow the fan (and duct) to be moved in the X and Z axis to position the duct near the extruder nozzle(s). There are two bracket variants available for use with both single and double extruder mounting brackets, depending upon your printer configuration.

A horizontal slider that fits in the dovetail of the above bracket, and contains the track for the vertical slider.

A vertical slider that fits in the above vertical track. The cooling fan duct (and fan) attach to this piece.

Of the 4 fan ducts available at the referenced Thing, I used the V3 bracket as a first try.
There are a couple different sizes of Z-brackets to connect the fan duct to the Z axis slider, for use to fit various configurations.

The horizontal slider has two holes for screws to fasten it to the track. Only one screw is necessary, depending on how it is positioned in the track.

A couple notes on the fan duct: The tip of the V3 duct which I printed, is only one perimeter wide, and can be delicate. It may have holes in it if your printer under-extrudes, as mine did at the time. You can beef it up with Superglue to fill any holes and stiffen the thin areas. Also, if it is positioned close to a MK8 type extruder head, it may soften due to heat radiated from the extruder, when the fan is off or on low speed. Gluing a piece of aluminum foil on the tip of the duct may prevent damage. A flexible adhesive like silicone rubber or latex caulk may work, as well as superglue.

The duct can be mounted using the holes that are formed when it is printed. The fan guard also contains mounting holes, so one set of mounting holes or the other may be cut off depending upon what works best for your printer. I ended up using the fan guard mounting holes for attaching the fan and duct to the bracket, and then later switched back to the mounting holes on the fan duct when I changed the orientation of the extruder block.

All in all, it works well and is acceptably stiff with the recently added stiffener. Maybe you can improve on the whole thing!

Update 12/3/17 I added a longer arm (zarm5), which I needed when I changed the mounting of the horizontal extruder mounting plate.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Geeetech I3 Pro Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 preferable (I used .3)

Notes:

Since screws are tapped into the brackets to hold pieces in the dovetail slot and the screws press against the bottom of the slot, use at least 3 perimeters and 3 top layers. On the last print I used 20% Hexagonal infill on the thicker mounting plate and stiffness was much improved.

Almost certainly the edges of the sliders will have to be sanded or filed to fit into the dovetail slot. Taper the lead-in slightly to make it easier to insert. 0.2 layer height will probably yield parts that need less fitting.

Screws threaded into the sliders are used to hold them securely. Warm the screw with a soldering iron while it is at the entrance of the hole. When warm, thread it in slowly until it gets more difficult to turn, and then reheat to continue.

After the parts are threaded, sand off the material thrown up on the back side of the slider. If done carefully, there won't be much or any material to remove.

author: Chank

description.text: Nikola Tesla's "Valvular Conduit" for your printing pleasure.
Print! May need a heated bed.  Works marginally well. Expect updates as I tweak the geometry.

comments.text: Has anybody tested this thing out? Does it work? Has anybody measured the difference in pressure at both ends? If you connect these in a ring wouldn't you create a flow going around the ring that converts heat into movement ?
comments.author: aleferna

comments.text: Your design doesn't work.
comments.author: Jesse0999

comments.text: The conduit doesn't completely stop flow in either direction, but it impedes flow in one direction significantly more than the other.  It has uses, but it's no replacement for a flapper valve.
comments.author: Jesse0999

comments.text: Tell that to the most influential genius of modern history, you ignoramus.
comments.author: Jesse0999

comments.text: Please elaborate.
comments.author: Jesse0999

comments.text: You may need to scale the STL up a bit for it to print correctly. Mine works a lot better scaled up.
comments.author: toehead

comments.text: So simple yet genius at the same time!  This is something I'd love to cut from clear acrylic and leave on my desk.
comments.author: FreeRider

comments.text: Sweet.. Tesla was the man!
comments.author: firepinto

title: E3D Chimera and Cyclops X-Carriage for Wilson 2 printer

description.text:
This is a X carriage for using the E3D Chimera/Cyclops print head (Chinese clone on the picture, works with genuine as well) on the Wilson 2 printer (LM10UU/LM10LUU bearings)

Carriage is based on the original design found at https://github.com/mjrice/Wilson2

The interface mount part is taken from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:833722

Fan mount has been removed as it's not necessary in my design.

4 holes allows you to secure/unsecure the throats of the head using an allen key.

Printer:

Customized prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

50% honeybomb

Notes:

Carriage printed using PLA, interface mount using ABS

title: Samsung Galaxy S4 w/Otterbox Charging Dock

description.text: This charging dock was my first real creation using OnShape cloud CAD. It is specific to Samsung Galaxy S4 with the OtterBox Commuter Series. I have tweaked the design since I printed my working version to make it a bit prettier, but the essential dimensions haven't changed, so everything should work out just fine.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

20%

Requirements

I had to cut off the little flap from the Otterbox that covers the charging port. I hated that thing anyway, so it was no loss to me...

You'll need a micro USB charging cable and some glue. Also, depending on the size and shape of the casing around the business end of the charging cable, you may want to have an Exacto Knife handy to trim away any areas for proper fit. Make sure, however, that you don't trim away too much (like I did, at first) because you do want a snug fit.

This is an adapter allowing you to convert a Canon EF lens and a 1.25" telescope eyepiece to a spyglass. I included M42 version as well. Photo lens have a good quality so a picture is very good (but upside down orientation is a little bit tricky to handle). You can easily get a zoom spyglass or very fast spyglass (with f/1.8 lens for example).
25mm eyepice and 200mm lens result in 8x magnification.

author: meteor64

description.text: This is my face. We used the 3d scanner described here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1491 and here: http://abarry.org/stereo to scan and then print the face. Update -- just printed a new version upside down for much better print resolution!

• Scan face into pointcloud.
  • Use Blender 3D to clean the pointcloud (import PLY, export as OBJ)
  • Open the cleaned pointcloud in Meshlab and:
    • a. Compute normals by Filters > Normals, Curvatures and Orientation > Compute normals for point sets. I used the default settings here.
    • b. Then compute a surface using Filters > Point Set > Poisson Reconstruction. For this, use an Octree Depth of 11 but all the other settings as the defaults. This will take 15-30 seconds to compute.
  • Once you've got the meshed face, save it as an STL and import it back into Blender. In Blender, add a block to the back of it and export it as an STL.
  • Skeinforge!
  • Print!

remixed_from.author: Coucoudexav02
remixed_from.title: Case for Touchscreen 7" - Raspberry Pi 2B - Cam

description.text:
I took the Frame from the "Case for TouchScreen 7" and remixed it to include game controls. More information to come including a list of materials.

My printer only prints up to 6" in all directions so I also split the frame in half.

I used the following image for connecting my buttons to the raspberry pi:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/DigitalLumberjack/mk_arcade_joystick_rpi/master/wiki/images/mk_joystick_arcade_GPIOsb+.png

For button wiring:
Take a look at the images for help but basically for each set of controls you need to wire in a common ground wire that plugs into the raspberry pie then you need one wire for each direction and button wired to the raspberry pi.

For wiring in the battery I followed this diagram:
https://learn.adafruit.com/7-portable-raspberry-pi-multitouch-tablet?view=all#circuit-diagram

OS:
Install Raspian Jesse:
https://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads/raspbian/

Ran update/upgrade
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get upgrade

Installed mk_arcade_joystick_rpi for testing
https://github.com/recalbox/mk_arcade_joystick_rpi and setup the auto load at startup (follow the directions on the site)

next I did the manual install of retropie following the directions here:
https://github.com/retropie/retropie-setup/wiki/manual-installation

*UPDATE***
I've updated the materials list to include items you will need for on board sound. I'm also testing a different battery and will update the list if it works out better. The current battery doesn't last very long.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

10% on most parts

Notes:

Most parts were printed at 10% infill accept for the controller plates, those I printed at 40% infill.

Directions for Build (Still working on these)
Print out all parts.

Set up the Raspberry Pi display following the directions here:
https://www.element14.com/community/docs/DOC-78156/l/raspberry-pi-7-touchscreen-display

Attach your buttons to the plates and then following the wiring diagram solder jumper wires to the buttons as well as solder in the common ground wire.

Take the Front Left and Front Right and Backmiddle parts out for the next step.

With the touchscreen facing down (on a clean cloth or something to protect the screen)

carefully position the front left and right pieces around the screen, then place the backmiddle piece around the pie.

Secure all of these pieces together and attach to the screen using the 4 mount points on the touchscreen.

Next secure the button plates to the front right and left parts and run your jumper wires to the Raspberry Pi following the diagram found here:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/DigitalLumberjack/mk_arcade_joystick_rpi/master/wiki/images/mk_joystick_arcade_GPIOsb+.png

Wiring in Power:
PowerBoost1000C
The slide switchs connect to the EN and GND pins the Adafruit PowerBoost1000C.
The 2500mAh batteries plugs into the JST connector on the PowerBoost1000C. You can charge the battery by connecting a microUSB cable.

Raspberry Pi 2:
Positive+ and -Negative pins on the PowerBoost1000C connect to the Pi on GPIO #2 for 5V power and GPIO # 6 for ground.

Wiring in Sound
you need to wire the stereo plug to the amp into the R+ and L+ pins with the ground (bare wire) wired to either l- or r- pins. You also need a small wire that connects l- to r-

Solder jumper wires to VDD and GND pins on amp. Connect wires to +positive and -negative pins on PowerBoost 1000c.

it should look like this minus the hdmi display card on the bottom right:
https://learn.adafruit.com/assets/29647

comments.text: Make sure you read all the directions they are the best I was able to come up with. Did you see this? https://raw.githubusercontent.com/DigitalLumberjack/mk_arcade_joystick_rpi/master/wiki/images/mk_joystick_arcade_GPIOsb+.png
comments.author: zenway9

comments.text: I saw it.  It says nothing about where the colored buttons go on the GPIO pins.  Can you take a closer picture of the wiring configuration?
comments.author: craiglitwiller

comments.text: Actually this image (https://raw.githubusercontent.com/DigitalLumberjack/mk_arcade_joystick_rpi/master/wiki/images/mk_joystick_arcade_GPIOsb+.png) shows the GPIO of a Raspberry Pi, It is this image that I used to wire mine up. I would have to completely disassemble mine to take any new pictures and unfortunately I gave mine away to a friend who really wanted it. I wired up mine to the Joystick 1 (green) sections. For instance my up button was wired to GPIO4 as shown in the picture, the down button was wired to GPIO17 etc. I'm sorry that I cant be much more help but this was a very much learn as I go project and I had to do a lot of trial and error. I uploaded this since I really enjoyed the learning/building process however I do not have a "100% step by step, if you do this i guarantee that it will work set of directions." Even the software has changed since I first put this up so a little experimentation / trial and error is going to be required. Perhaps start here: https://github.com/recalbox/mk_arcade_joystick_rpi to see if you have things working and then move on? Thats what I did. I made sure that I could wire up the buttons, trigger them on the Pie and then I moved on from there. Again I'm really sorry that your having issues but for me the issues and over coming them were some of the funnest parts of this project.
comments.author: zenway9

comments.text: It shouldn't matter since all you are doing is creating a common ground to the Raspberry Pi but the images I created are looking at it from the front. the other side of the buttons then each connect to their own area on the pi. I added two more images, sorry not super easy to see but may help you.

description.text: I couldn't find a Civil War bullet, so I made my own. I did this off of memory, and then compared it to a replica and an actual Civil War bullet. This is a relatively fast print. I printed one out in 22 minutes with the standard setting on the Dremel, and about 45 minutes on the Dremel's best quality.
I used a Dremel Idea builder with the standard settings on it. I did add a raft, but it was not necessary.

title: 2 Ch Relay board mountable snap case

description.text:
I know there are some of these out there, but none suited my application, so here is my version of a housing for the common 2 channel relay boards (Sainsmart/Sunfounder).
The board is mounted with 4x M3 screws, 2 of which need to have a rather small head, due to the spacing of the connectors on the PCB (you can see what i mean in the picture). The top just snaps on.

Attention!
The type of board used here is usually rather cheap and due to this the dimensions and positions of through holes may vary.

Thanks to Richard Hornung for the relay board model:
https://grabcad.com/library/sainsmart-2-channel-relay-module-1

Printer:

Original Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer

Infill:

10 %

Notes:

Print time:
Bottom - 1h 30m
Top - 35m

remixed_from.author: chapulina
remixed_from.title: Rubik's cube for the blind (fully printable)

title: Rubiks cube for the blind (using original Rubiks core)

description.text: This is a version of the Rubiks cube for the blind that uses the core from an original Rubiks Cube instead of a fully printed one.

If you print all of the stl's that are labeled 'plate' you will get all of the pieces, most of them are the same as the original, I just include them for convenience. The only new pieces are the center_outer_xxx_cap.stl's (xxx replaced with each individual cap type) and the center_outer_cap_plate.stl that has them all combined. You'll need glue (I used super glue) to combine all the printed parts together following the instructions of the original Rubiks cube for the blind http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9913, except for the printed core part of it. Then, take your original Rubiks core and remove the caps that hold the colored stickers on all 6 sides. It's a bit difficult, but I managed to pop them off using a razor blade. Once those are off, replace the caps with the printed ones, use some super glue or something to attach them. Assemble the rest of the cube using your printed parts and you're done!

comments.text: I Printed one with the original core, unfortunatly the pieces were a little bit to big & to tight to fit to the original layout. I printed a second time with 96% Scale and this worked fine, now i have good present for my blind friend, thanks for sharing.
comments.author: domi1l

comments.text: I've a son who is blind who was a whiz at solving the original Rubic's Cube for the blind. He literally wore the many he's had to pieces and we've not been successful at finding a new source. Having tried almost all the alternative ones since, we'd love a chance to purchase one of these for him. Does anyone who comes to this site make them?
comments.author: sherrylowry

comments.text: I would offer to build you one myself, but my printing quality is only sub-par right now. But, perhaps I could help another way. If you take the model files here (the ones that have '_plate' in their names) and take them to http://www.shapeways.comwww.shapeways.com, you can have a professional company print the pieces up for you in whatever materials/colors you wish. It's a bit expensive, but their quality is good. You may also want to have the model files modified so it doesn't require gluing the parts together. Once printed, all you need is an original rubix cube so you can re-use it's core with the new parts.
comments.author: sherrylowry

comments.text: Nice! I'm glad it fit the core :) And nice move with the caps!
comments.author: chapulina

comments.text: It is a fantastic idea!!!!!! Congratulations!!!! Nice work. :)
comments.author: kukarleo

comments.text: Thanks!  I tried the fully printable core first but failed miserably, lol.  This is actually a result of me being lazy and just using a core that already worked.  All I needed to do was design new end-caps for the center pieces so they matched the rest of the cube.
comments.author: kukarleo

author: Lochemage

description.text:
Technically this isn't a full remix, just the addition of a part for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1384316

This case is awesome, except for the tabs which do break off very easily. I knocked together this addition as a quick fix that saves having to reprint the entire back cover if the tabs break off. Just slide these rails onto the sides of the back cover where the tabs were, and you should be good to go. While this will introduce a slight gab that wasn't there previously, it's better than no back at all.

My next step will be to further modify the design by adding a gap/groove of some kind to the support legs themselves that will accept/hold the back cover.

description.text:
This is a knob that I made in fusion 360 to replace one missing from my father's Crosley CR-9 Select-o-matic (an AM/FM/Cassette player styled to look like those mid twentieth century tabletop jukeboxes that you'll see at Johnny Rockets and similar places).

The photo shows one of the originals that I used for measurements, and the resulting print. I've made a small change since the photo, to fillet the edges of the knob and the ridges a little. The original is chromed plastic, so matching with a filament would've been quite difficult and we cared more about functionality.

print_settings.Notes:: Die Schale drucke ich stehend (aus ABS, geschlossene Seite unten, mit Raft und Support), der Grundhalter wird liegend gedruckt (ABS, ohne Raft, mit Support). Wenn sich die Teile sehr schwer ineinander schieben lassen, dann wird eben der Grundträger mittels Schmirgelleinen etwas nachgearbeitet. Ansonsten ist es schon ok, wenn sich die Teile schwer ineinander schieben lassen! Das Silikon-Keypad lässt sich mithilfe von etwas Seifenwasser am Rand leichter einschieben - notfalls kann man die Schale etwas mittels Schmirgelleinen nacharbeiten.

description.text: Diese Halterung dient zur Befestigung eines USB-Silikon-Keypads (Keysonic 12523) am Trainingsgerät (Ergometerlenker, Crosstrainer-Holm, Bikelenker o.ä.). Die Halterung besteht aus zwei Teilen: Dem Grundträger und der Schale. Das Keypad wird in die Schale und die Schale wird auf den Grundträger geschoben. Der Grundträger kann um 90 gedreht werden zur senkrechten oder waagrechten Montage. Der Grundträger wird zuerst mit stabilem O-Ring (suche nach passendem Pressluft O-Ring mit ca. 3 mm Durchmesser) am Trainingsgerät befestigt und anschliessend die Schale mit eingeschobenem Keypad aufgeschoben (siehe Bilder).

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

high

Notes:

Die Schale drucke ich stehend (aus ABS, geschlossene Seite unten, mit Raft und Support), der Grundhalter wird liegend gedruckt (ABS, ohne Raft, mit Support). Wenn sich die Teile sehr schwer ineinander schieben lassen, dann wird eben der Grundträger mittels Schmirgelleinen etwas nachgearbeitet. Ansonsten ist es schon ok, wenn sich die Teile schwer ineinander schieben lassen! Das Silikon-Keypad lässt sich mithilfe von etwas Seifenwasser am Rand leichter einschieben - notfalls kann man die Schale etwas mittels Schmirgelleinen nacharbeiten.

description.text: I wanted a desktop power supply and had an extra computer power supply laying around. So I made an enclosure that I put the computer power supply into and bought a few items to make it nice. This supply has 5 volt output, 12 volt output and an adjustable 0-12 volt output.

Simply print one of everything and two tops. (it actually is the top and bottom) the power supply can be mounted with the four 3mm x 10mm flat head screws. The sides can then be bolted to the top and bottom using the eight 3mm x 20mm bolts and 8 3mm nuts. (the nuts will be pressed into the top and bottom and will then not fall back out.) the front and back will snap into the grooves in the sides, top and bottom of the box. For the power connections I connected the black and green wire to the power switch and the yellow wire to one of the red banana plug posts (12 volt) and a red wire to the other red banana plug post. Both of the black banana plug posts are then connected to black wires. The hole below the switch is for a potentiometer that can be connected to a voltage regulator do it yourself kit. I connected 3 wires from the potentiometer leads to the places on the do it yourself voltage regulator board where the small potentiometer should go. The inputs to the regulator board are connected to the yellow and black wires and the outputs will go into the front in the bottom two holes. Items required:
1) Banana Jacks plugs (Radio Shack #271-661)
2) Switch (Radio Shack 275-0712)
3) Potentiometer (for adjustable power kit)
4) Power regulator kit (Velleman P1823)
5) Coolmax Micro ATX 300w Power Supply (http://www.frys.com/product/5841263?site=sr:SEARCH:MAIN_RSLT_PG)
6) four 3mm x 10mm flat head screw
7) eight 3mm x 20mm flat head screw
8) eight 3mm nuts

title: New Matter MOD-t Cura and Slic3r settings

description.text:
Here I share the profiles I'm using to successfully print objects with my New Matter MOD-t firmware ver. 0.15.0, using:

  • Cura ver. 15.x (tested with 15.04.3, 15.04.5 and 15.04.6)
  • Cura ver. 2.x (tested with 2.5 and 2.6)
  • Cura ver. 3.x (tested with 3.03 and 3.1)
  • Slic3r ver. 1.2.9.

To be noted that with latest firmwares I where not able to complete other than a very small object (frequently not that either...) sliced with Slic3r due to a bug in MOD-t firmware that evaluate wrongly slic3r gcode, generating blobs of extrusion here and there that will make the bed hop on pinion rods.
So slic3r is not encouraged, until it will be fixed in the firmware... (sigh!)

I'll update these profiles as I experiment and find better values, so here is the reference of last time I've updated them:

  • Cura 15.04.x settings: 06 February 2017
  • Cura 2.x settings: 07 June 2017
  • Slic3r settings: 18 October 2016

If you have improvements, corrections, concerns, whatever you want please write me in comments :)

DISCLAIMER: you'll take all te risk of using these profiles, They are not official as I'm not in any way linked to New Matter. I take no liabilities if something bad happens to your 3D printer, you and only YOU are the responsible of the correct operation of your printer.

Install MOD-t in Cura 15.04.x
  1. Install latest version of Cura on the branch 15.04 from Ultimaker site.
  2. Open Cura. The "add new machine widard" opens (or, if you didn't just installed Cura, just go to Machine -> Add new machine... to open the same dialog). Press Next, select other and press Next, select Custom, press Next and insert these data:
    Machine name: MOD-t
    Machine width X (mm): 155.4
    Machine depth Y (mm): 104.6
    Machine height Z (mm): 130
    Nozzle size (mm): 0.4
    Heated bed: NO
    Bed center is 0,0,0 (RoStock): YES
    Then press Finish
  3. Now click on the File -> Open profile... menu and select the Cura_Profile_Backup_4.ini to load a base working profile, ready to be customized based on your needs.
  4. Click on Start/End-GCode tab and verify that GCode present is the same as the files start_gcode.txt for start.code and end_gcode.txt for end.code. If not overwrite it with the content of those file with copy/paste.

Ok, you're ready to load the stl file, slice it experimenting different parameters and print it!

CHANGELOG

06 February 2017

  • Updated retraction speed to the real maximum speed MOD-t can achieve: 6 mm/s (all greater values was capped at 6 mm/s)
  • Returned to 2mm of retraction. In the previous profile that was 4, trying to address a severe oozing I was facing with some objects.
  • Skirt enabled by default. I use them all the time as it can help a little bit to have a steady initial extrusion.

30 June 2016

  • Updated start / end gcode to latest official provided. Adapted start gcode to not overlap to my Bed Clips (so it's greatly adviced to use this profile when using clips!)
  • Implemented z-hop as per New Matter engineers advice to reduce bed slipping probability
  • Removed skirt

05 May 2016

  • Added start/end gcode that was not loading correctly from profile
  • Profile was not loading correctly

04 May 2016

  • Initial release

Install MOD-t in Slic3r 1.2.9
  1. Download Slic3r from the Slic3r website
  2. Extract the zip content in a folder, let's assume c:\Slic3r
  3. Create a link to c:\Slic3r\Slic3r.exe on the Desktop and Start Menu for easy open in the future (as Slic3r has not to be installed)
  4. Open it!
  5. Click in the upper menu on File -> Load config bundle... and open the Slic3r_config_bundle 6.ini file (that you have already downloaded to your PC from Thing files)

Here we go! You're ready to use MOD-t with Slic3r!

Slic3r settings

Slic3r settings are divided in three groups:

  • Print settings to control how to print (use the printer MOD-t)
  • Filament settings to customize temperature, filament diameter and cooling options
  • Printer settings to control 3d printer peculiarities.

There is no need to say you'll change every time Print settings to adapt to the desired settings in wich you want to print a specific model.
For that reason I've created several profiles with most useful (for me) print settings combination.
The profiles have this convention: [layer height]-[quality]-[perimeter thickness]-[supports]
Where every of those fields can assume these values:

  • layer height: 100µm, 200µm or 300µm
  • quality: HQ (high quality) or LQ (low quality). The first will print slowly, the second faster.
  • perimeter thickness: MIN (small perimeters for not resistant objects), 2mm (for medium resistant objects) and FILL (for extra strong, 100% filled objects)
  • supports: sup (generates supports) or no sup (don't generate supports)
CHANGELOG

18 October 2016

  • Specified 0.4mm as extrusion width instead of 0 (automatic) as often top solid infill has space between extrusion lines, like it was underextruding. With this settings I like more the surfaces.
  • Increased first layer, small perimeters and small gap speed from 7 to 15 as they was really slow... No noticeable differences using the new speed but could vastly improve speed
  • Changed first layer from 150% to 0.3mm so that if you change the layer height you'll not have to change the first layer due to a wrong 150% of what you insert
  • Changed infill every layer 2 to 1 as that will improve the infill quality

30 June 2016

  • Updated start / end gcode to latest official provided. Adapted start gcode to not overlap to my Bed Clips (so it's greatly adviced to use this profile when using clips!)
  • Implemented z-hop as per New Matter engineers advice to reduce bed slipping probability
  • Reduced xy_size_compensation to -0.1 as firmware 0.13 and newer are more precise.

05 May 2016

  • Corrected xy_size_compensation, it was -0.3 for HQ and -0.4 for LQ but this is the clearance added to both sides so it was divided by two and is now equal to -0.15 for both LQ and HQ.

04 May 2016

  • Initial release

Install MOD-t in Cura 2.x or 3.x (PC)
  1. Install Cura 2.x or 3.x from Ultimaker site
  2. Copy the provided modt.def.json file in the Program files\Cura 2.x\resources\definitions folder and the modt_platform.stl file into Program Files\Cura 2.x\resources\meshes
  3. Open Cura. The Add new printer wizard shows. Select MODt printer in the Other section.
  4. Take some time to select what parameters are important to you and to show in Settings -> Configure setting visibility
  5. Please ensure that the following parameters on the right panels are as follow:
    SHELL
    • Top/Bottom Thickness: a multiple of the Layer Height
    • Horizontal Expansion: -0.2
      MATERIAL
    • Printing Temperature: 210
    • Flow: 95% (it really depends on your filament type and material. My BQ filaments are better printed with 95 or even 90% flow, even if they are 1.75 diameter)
    • Retraction speed: 6
    • Retraction Minimum Travel: 10
    • Maximum Retraction Count: 10
    • Minimum Extrusion Distance Window: 2
      SPEED
    • Travel speed: 60 (you can set 80 but absolutely not the proposed 120!!! I prefer 60 to reduce the probability that bed will hop on pinion rods... Very bad...)
      TRAVEL
    • Z Hop When Retracted: yes
    • Z Hop Height: 2
      BUILD PLATE ADHESION
    • Build Plate Adhesion Type: Skirt
    • Skirt Line Count: 1
    • Skirt/Brim Minimum Length: 100

Other than that remember to select the appropriate settings for every print like support, speed, thicknesses, etc.
I'll make some profiles to use like I did for Slic3r.

Install MOD-t in Cura 2.x or 3.x (Mac)

The user hsus (thank you!) wrote some hints in the comments on how to make that work on the Mac. Here are his exact words for everyone's reference:
Right click the application, show contents, go into the Resources folder, in there is another resources folder which contains the meshes and definitions folders. Place modt.def.json in "definitions" and modt_platform.stl in "meshes".
After doing this the app won't run due to security reasons. Open up terminal and execute sudo xattr -cr '/Applications/Ultimaker Cura.app' and go through the rest of the steps as provided.

CHANGELOG

07 June 2017

  • Initial release

I'm using your guide to configure Cura 3.1 for the NM Mod-T on a Mac. Currently printing my first model.
Just a short note for other MacOS users;
Adding the platform and machine definitions differs a (tiny) bit on the Mac:
Right click the application, show contents, go into the Resources folder, in there is another resources folder which contains the meshes and definitions folders. Place modt.def.json in "definitions" and modt_platform.stl in "meshes".
After doing this the app won't run due to security reasons. Open up terminal and execute sudo xattr -cr '/Applications/Ultimaker Cura.app' and go through the rest of the steps as provided.

comments.text:
Sorry for late reply, I'm so busy with my work lately... At the moment there is no risks but that's a liability statement. Assume I publish a wrong gcode start/end sequence that is not correctly handled by MOD-t firmware and the hotend thermal fuse will broke (actually I'm not aware of such a possibility, it's just an hypothesis) I don't want to refund for that as I'm using the printer in my spare time and I wanted to share my experience with other people in the hope that will be of value to them helping to print better with their printer.
Actually, however, every not expected thing that will happen on the firmware will lead to a firmware reboot so temperature will go down to cold and the printer will stop all movements. That's a good thing in terms of security, a bad thing in terms of printed waste ;)
That's all :)

comments.text:
Hey, I have no words! Not only for your kind words, you know what I mean :) Thank you so much man!
So you're using Slic3r with MOD-t. With the latest printer firmware? Did you ever suffer from the big blobs that happens printing with Slic3r sliced models? I'm pushing info and details to the firmware developer but that bug is still there. Some gcode files (not all but many) suffer from that and could happen even with Cura, even if it it's much less frequent.
I've managed also to print CraftWare gcode, I was impressed by that free slicer! I'll add instructions on how to configure it in this page.
comments.author: Jeutnarg

comments.text:
You're very welcome.
Firmware... well, I bought it just a week or so ago, so I'd assume it's on the latest.
Big blobs have happened to me on this print: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:122723 for the swamp/death box. There was one blob on a corner of the top piece, one blob on the left-hand, upper detail of the skull, a blob between the mustache-thingies, and one more but I forget where (I gave away the piece, so I can't check.)
I've only seen blobs on flat vertical sections, and I don't have many of those in my prints.
comments.author: energywave

comments.text: Ok. I asked because it's a problem that annoy me so much... With Cura happened one time only, with Slic3r happens much more frequently. However I had feedback recently from the firmware developer at New Matter about this. I think that there is a problem with retraction speed configured in profile (inherited from the official profile). I'll do some test with known models that generate ugly blobs and, if that's helps as I hope, I'll update the profiles here.

comments.text:
Right, sorry for haven't posted any update. I've tested setting the maximum allowed retraction from the New Matter firmware developer but that didn't helped as the firmware will cap to the maximum allowed speed.
New Matter is working on a firmware update that will improve the path planner and seems to mitigate the issue.
I'll update the profiles, however, with the correct speed. And the procedure to set up CraftWare to slice for MOD-t :)
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: That would be great. I'm using Cura 2.x, but I can reverse engineer your profile to get mine configured.
comments.author: energywave

comments.text:
The maximum retraction speed (E axis) is 360 mm/min or 6 mm/sec so, yes, that's a similar value of what you said. At beginning that seemed ridiculous to me too but that's the value that MOD-t is using when inserting 300, as 6 mm/sec is the maximum value that firmware is capping that value. And if you think about it 6 mm of filament move in one second is not so slow. At the same time think about 300 mm in one second... that value is impossible. 30 cm of filament move in one second? With sub mm precision? That was a wrong value.
That said, are you using Cura 2.x with MOD-t? I've tried it when it was new but I didn't liked the parameters organization (I love Slic3r for that). But how are prints? I can add here the Cura 2.x profile as well, if that produce good prints. What's your experience?
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: Ah, we're talking about two different settings. I wasn't clear enough. 6mm/s is the retraction speed, but I meant 4.5mm looked like the preset retraction distance in Astroprint.
comments.author: energywave

comments.text:
Oh well, sorry, my fault :) Yes, 4,5mm retraction is a lot... I'm usually using 2mm as the MOD-t extruder tends to miss some material after every retraction... Using a higher value can get things even worse. They're working on that too but that's a complex matter.
Oh ok, you're waiting for your MOD-t, so you never printed with Cura 2.x on it. I can suggest you to start using the old Cura, just to get some confidence with the printer, then try to use Cura 2.x. I'll try again myself too in the near future.
Thank you for the offer of your profile, if you'll send them and I'll publish them I'll write credit to you.

Luckily, I have a yahoo account I use for spam so I used that address, however they still never sent me a download link.  Any chance you could host your files on a different site that doesn't require an email address?  I don't mean to complain because I know you guys are doing the heavy lifting for the rest of us MOD-t owners, so I'm sure I can speak for everyone when I say we really appreciate it! comments.author: A_Fairman

comments.text: I installed Cura 15 just so I could get a look at the profile you posted. Yours varies significantly from NewMatter's Cura profile. They use 2mm, which is what I normally use, and you have yours configured for 4mm. Additionally, with regard to retract, you have your speed set at 300, but cura doesn't measure speed like Simplify3D does. 300 is 300mm/s, which is much too fast. If the firmware caps it a 6mm/s, then that setting isn't doing any harm, but it isn't correct either. I run my "normal" sized printers at 30mm/s retract speed and 2mm distance. NewMatter recommends 15mm/s and 2mm.
comments.author: energywave

comments.text:
Thank you for the feedback! Well, I forgot to revert that 4mm retraction that was an update from the ver.3 trying to address the severe oozing I was facing (that seems much better with the new beta firmware). 4mm was not helping, however.
2mm was the amount I was using before and that I'm using now (I'll try to update the profiles this weekend).
The 300 mm/sec speed was inherited from the official New Matter profile, the upper limit is 6mm/sec to every higher value will be limited by firmware to 6. I'm using 6 now, as I believe it's more wise (I'll update this too in the profiles).
Can you tell me where New Matter recommend 15mm/sec? That's weird, knowing the upper limit of 6... :)
Sorry I haven't time now to test your profiles as I'm working hard. Maybe monday I'll give it a try and let you know. Thank you very much, in the meanwhile!!!

title: Extruder using 6mm Burr instead of hobbed bolt for Prusa i3

description.text:
I had no luck making a hob bolt, so this is a remix of a no-hob extruder idea I liked but instead of a dremel tool, my design uses a tungsten carbide burr 6mm shaft, 5/8"x 1/4" burr , Linbide SB-1MM http://www.linbide.co.nz/product.php?p=290 was about $26. It works perfectly and solved all my retraction issues. It was made with Tinkercad, my favorite design tool download the source and edit it if you need to to perhaps fit a different extruder, this one will fit a Budish or J-Head with a mounting plate.
https://tinkercad.com/things/logamTuWj12
https://tinkercad.com/things/7SBuH24RSak-extruder-with-burr
Basically this is a Wade extruder variation I'm using for 3mm PLA. I have not yet uploaded the idler yet but any standard Wade idler for 3mm filament will work as that is all I used.
The two bearings needed for the burr are 6mm ID 19mm OD and 6mm width.

Most of this thing is easy to figure out, I don't yet have an idler stl uploaded, I will have to steal one from somewhere else as a friend made mine from a standard wade extruder. The key to this is the Linbide burr, having a smaller shaft than the burr means the burr will not fall out into the bearing. This object is made in TinkerCAD which is online and free, if things don't fit it is made by grouping objects that are either solids or holes together so try un-grouping things as a first step to editing stuff. It is also designed to fit a Prusa i3 with the vertically spaced X rails it may fit other designs but I don't know. I live in a metric country, New Zealand, so all bolt holes and captive nuts etc are metric. You will find the burr shaft will not fit into the 6mm ID bearing as they are both exactly 6mm. I put the burr in the drill (with the burr end in the chuck) and ran wet and dry sandpaper for a few minutes on the shaft until it was a firm hand pushed fit BOM
printed
x1 idler (standard wade)
x1 main body x1 machine tungsten carbide burr 6mm shaft, 5/8"x 1/4" burr
Linbide SB-1MM was about $20
x1 nema 17 motor
x3 bolts to hold motor, 3mm x 15mm
x2 bearings 6 ID, 19 OD, 6 Width
x1 idler bearing
x1 20mm of 8mm shaft for idler
x1 3mm x 30mm bolt and nut
x2 4mm x 70mm nut and bolts (for idler tension)
x2 springs to fit over 70mm bolts

author: merohar

description.text: I added a twist to Jack from The Nightmare Before Christmas. He needed to be more hip and cool. It is one of my favorite movies and I wanted to change his character a bit. I added a top hat and some glasses.

Step 1

In thingiverse, I choose an item. There you can choose whatever you like. I choose Jack.

Step 2

I converted it to a stl and uploaded it to blender.

Step 3

There I was able to create a top hat by using the shape of a square and a circle. I extruded them both and place it on his head.

Step 4

I choose two circles to create a pair of sunglasses and aligned it with his eyes.I also slightly extruded the circles also.

Step 5

I then choose a square shape again and made a rectangle to create the support for the glasses and aligned them both on the side of his head and made sure it touch the circles. Also, I created a bridge in the middle for the nose stand.

description.text: Squirtle Squad Leader from Pokemon. I thought that since squirtle is the leader, he needed to be more cool and should look more like a leader. Therefore, I added a pair of glasses and a cane to him.

Step 1

I uploaded squirtle from the sketchup warehouse and I choose squirtle.

Step 2

I modify him there, and choose two circles and aligned them with his eyes.

Step 3

I extruded the circles slightly. Then with the line tool, I created a lone across the circle.

Step 4

It should create two separate objects. Then choose the eraser tool and delete the top object.

Step 5

I choose the rectangle shape and extruded two pairs of them to create the stand for the ears.

Step 6

Aligned them both on the side of the head and made sure it touch the shades in front of the eyes.

Step 7

I choose a rectangle and extruded it slightly and place it on his hand and added a circle to create the curve of the hand stand.

Step 8

I used the line tool to create the shape, then used the eraser tool to remove the rest.

print_settings.Notes:: Designed to be printed in spiral vase mode.

description.text:
We have created a new Rocket Ship since everyone enjoyed the other one so much. With this new design you can now print in spiral vase mode. In this mode, you print the perimeter as one continuous line and the z-axis raises during the print causing a clean exterior with no seams. This mode also saves a lot of plastic and prints much faster.

Check out the original gCreate Rocket Ship here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:427789

Refer to google to see what slicing engines have spiral vase mode. Of course you can still print the normal way with several walls and infill is not required.

Oh and it's a manifold model.

In the photo we tried (4) different Filaments:
Red: PolyMaker PolyMax PLA (http://www.polymaker.com/shop/polymax/)
Blue: 3D Print Life Enviro ABS (http://www.3dprintlife.com/)
Silver: Hatchbox Silver PLA (https://www.facebook.com/HATCHBOX3D/)
Black: ColorFabb PLA/PHA (http://colorfabb.com/pla-pha)

New! Check out the PolyMaker PolyFlex material print video here: https://www.instagram.com/p/BFWyqKkoajh/?taken-by=gcreate3d

Printed on a gMax 1.5+ by gCreate
Check out our site for more information http://www.gcreate.com

Printer:

gMax 1.5+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

Not Needed

Notes:

Designed to be printed in spiral vase mode.

comments.text: As others have commented, the model has a few problems with angles that have you air-printing unless you slice it really thin and print it really slow to get some support from previous layers without the plastic being pulled off as the nozzle pulls it around.  The little rings around the engine pod nozzles are bad as is the top of the window "glass", but the worst spot is the same place where your blue and gray prints broke off - as shown in your picture.   Softening the angles, if possible, would be nice.
comments.author: robertwallace

comments.text: Doesn't work very well at all for vase mode at larger scales... The model need to be edited to remove overhangs greater than 45 degrees.  Please can you add fillet radii to these areas?
